title: Bill Gates upgrades his stay at the Four Seasons
text:
One job move to start: Goldman Sachs has hired ex-McKinsey executive Kevin Sneader to serve as the bank's co-president in Asia-Pacific, months after he was ousted from the global consulting firm. Full story here.

Bill Gates and a Saudi royal shake hands over the Four Seasons

Roughly seven miles apart in Riyadh are two buildings that, for different reasons, occupy a special place in the life of Saudi Arabia's Prince Alwaleed bin Talal.

Sheathed in aluminium and sparkling glass, the 99-storey Kingdom Center is the glitzier of the pair. 

A giant kettlebell of a skyscraper, it was developed by Prince Alwaleed's Kingdom Holdings investment vehicle, through which he has amassed a vast portfolio of assets including a stake in the Four Seasons. The hotel chain occupies 237 guest rooms in the tower.

The second building, the Ritz-Carlton, is no less opulent, but if Prince Alwaleed has mixed feelings about the sprawling neoclassical estate, it may not be a question of mere architectural taste. 

The billionaire was among the more than 100 high-profile Saudis who were detained there in 2017 as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman consolidated power in the kingdom.

On Wednesday Prince Alwaleed agreed to sell half of his Four Seasons stake to Bill Gates' investment vehicle Cascade.

The two men have shared ownership of the chain since they collaborated on a 2007 deal to take it private for $3.4bn — Wednesday's deal values the hotel group at $10bn, including debt. 

It's the first big transaction made by Gates since his split from Melinda French Gates earlier this year, an event that triggered the division of one of America's largest private fortunes and raised questions about the future of one of its most prominent charitable foundations.

Prince Alwaleed's vast fortune, too, has been a subject of speculation. 

Unlike several other detainees who quietly agreed to make large payments as redress for allegedly corrupt activities, Prince Alwaleed told Reuters at the time of his 2018 release that he wanted to leave the Ritz in “complete vindication”, and didn't expect any assets to be transferred to the state.

The terms of the Saudi tycoon's partial exit from his Four Seasons investment, at least, are unambiguous. Kingdom Holdings said it expected to realise a gain of $1.6bn on the 24 per cent stake that it is selling. 

The quick-fire round: public auctions make a comeback (of sorts) 

Auctions for control of publicly traded companies, overseen by the UK's Takeover Panel, haven't been a big feature of the country's M&A landscape until the past few years. 

That began to change notably in 2018 when the auction process was used to settle the future of pay-TV group Sky, which resulted in a £30bn knockout bid from US company Comcast.

This year, in the middle of a frenzy to buy London-listed companies, the process is starting to feature more prominently. 

First, the panel planned an auction for the security company G4S in February. One of the bidders, private equity-backed GardaWorld, promptly stepped back in February after making a hostile bid last year, and paved the way for a sale to US rival Allied Universal.

Then it planned one for Vectura, the inhaler business at the centre of a bidding war between private equity group Carlyle and Philip Morris International, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes. In response, Carlyle quickly said it wouldn't raise its price, so the auction never got off the ground. 

Now it could hold one for Morrisons, the UK supermarket that two private equity consortiums are fighting for. It said on Wednesday that it was having “discussions around an orderly framework for the resolution of this competitive situation”, possibly via an auction.

US buyout group Clayton, Dubilier & Rice is in the lead in the Morrisons battle, but a rival group led by SoftBank-owned Fortress hasn't gone away and it has urged shareholders not to act yet. 

Participants on both sides have thought for a while that it may head in this direction, since the takeover battle has dragged on for months, causing uncertainty.

The point of the auctions process is to bring things to a head — sometimes with several days of game theory playing out in the public domain and sometimes with a speedy capitulation. We'll find out in the next few weeks which it will be. 

‘Failure is not a crime': the trial of Elizabeth Holmes begins

As opening statements kicked off on Wednesday in the trial of Elizabeth Holmes, Silicon Valley's best and brightest were likely watching with bated breath.

And that's not just because they're curious whether Holmes, who prosecutors allege deliberately misled investors and patients about the efficacy of her start-up Theranos's blood-testing technology, will be found guilty.

As DD's Miles Kruppa reports from the courthouse in San Jose, Holmes's lawyers began their defence by arguing her failure to build Theranos into a viable business wasn't a crime.

“Elizabeth Holmes did not go to work every day intending to lie, cheat and steal . . . Trying your hardest and coming up short is not a crime,” Lance Wade, an attorney for Holmes, told jurors during opening arguments. 

If convicted, Holmes faces up to 20 years in prison — which would make her one of just a few prominent figures in Silicon Valley accused of wrongdoing and actually going to jail for it.

Anthony Levandowski, the co-founder of Google's self-driving car project who was sentenced to prison for stealing trade secrets and allegedly using them to help build a rival programme at Uber, came close. However, he was pardoned by former president Donald Trump. 

But if prosecutors can convince the jury that Holmes knew her blood-testing devices didn't accurately perform the range of tests she claimed, the case could mark a major affront to Silicon Valley's hype and hubris-fuelled culture, in which sweeping statements are often made in the name of innovation.

Job moves

  • Credit Suisse has appointed Rafael Lorenzo as its chief compliance officer. Lorenzo, who has run the bank's internal audit division since 2017, will take over from Lara Warner, who departed alongside at least six other senior executives in a management overhaul in the wake of twin crises at Archegos Capital and Greensill Capital.

  • American International Group chief executive Peter Zaffino will take on the additional role of chair, succeeding Brian Duperreault, who will retire from the board at the end of this year.

  • Heather King, formerly a top lawyer for Theranos, has left her partnership at Boies Schiller Flexner in San Francisco, per Bloomberg Law.

  • Deutsche Bank has appointed Beau Bohm as co-head of equity capital markets origination and advisory in the Americas, based in New York. He returns to the German lender, where he worked until 2009, from Wells Fargo, where was head of TMT capital markets.

  • Barclays has appointed Davide Sala as a managing director and head of industrials M&A for Europe, the Middle East and Africa. He joins from Credit Suisse, where he led multiple industrials banking units.

  • Citigroup has appointed Brian Truesdale as chair of global technology banking, capital markets and advisory. He was previously global head of software investment banking at JPMorgan Chase.

  • Beatrice Devillon-Cohen has been appointed as an independent non-executive to the board of MUFG Securities Emea. She previously spent 25 years at Société Générale, holding roles at the board and executive committee level and currently sits on the European Investment Bank's risk committee.

  • Houlihan Lokey has hired Tom Carlson as a managing director in its oil and gas group, based in Houston. He was previously a managing director in BMO Capital Markets' energy group.
